task.title: Basic Maintenance
task.shortdesc: Essential maintenance procedures for keeping your vehicle in optimal condition.

ul.li: Ensure vehicle is parked on a level surface
Engine should be off and cool for most procedures
Have appropriate tools and safety equipment ready
Consult your vehicle's owner manual for specific recommendations

context.p: Regular maintenance extends your vehicle's lifespan, improves reliability, maintains fuel efficiency, and enhances safety. The following tasks represent fundamental maintenance procedures that most owners can perform.

step.cmd: Check engine oil level and condition

ol.li: Locate the dipstick (usually has a brightly colored handle)
Pull it out and wipe clean with a lint-free cloth
Reinsert fully and remove again to check level
Oil should be between MIN and MAX marks
Inspect oil color and consistency - should be amber to light brown, not black or gritty
If low, add manufacturer-recommended oil type in small increments

info.p: Frequency: Monthly and before long trips

ol.li: Check tire pressure when tires are cold using a quality gauge
Compare readings to specifications (found on driver's door jamb sticker)
Add air as needed to reach recommended pressure
Inspect tires for wear, damage, and foreign objects
Check tread depth using a tread depth gauge or the penny test
Verify spare tire condition and pressure

info.p: Frequency: Monthly and before long trips

ol.li: Turn on headlights and verify both low and high beams work
Check that tail lights, brake lights, and license plate lights function
Test turn signals and hazard lights
Verify reverse lights operate when transmission is in reverse
Check any fog lights or auxiliary lighting
Replace any burned-out bulbs promptly
Coolant/antifreeze: Check level in the overflow reservoir when engine is cool
Brake fluid: Verify level in the master cylinder reservoir
Power steering fluid: Check reservoir level (if applicable)
Transmission fluid: Follow manufacturer's procedure for checking (some require engine running)
Windshield washer fluid: Fill to appropriate level
With engine off, check drive belts for cracks, fraying, or glazing
Verify belt tension is adequate (not too loose or tight)
Inspect all visible hoses for leaks, bulges, cracks, or hardening
Check hose connections for secure fit and absence of leaks
Inspect battery terminals for corrosion (white or blue-green powder)
Clean terminals if necessary using a battery cleaning brush and solution
Check that battery is securely mounted
For non-sealed batteries, check electrolyte level and add distilled water if needed
Consider using a multimeter or battery tester to check battery health

result.p: Regular performance of these basic maintenance tasks will help ensure your vehicle operates reliably and efficiently. You'll also be able to identify potential problems before they become serious, reducing the likelihood of breakdowns and expensive repairs.

example.p: Create a maintenance log to track when you perform each task. This helps maintain a regular schedule and provides documentation of your vehicle's service history, which can be valuable when selling the vehicle.
